What is "redfish test"?
After your changes it is still possible to use BMCWEB_ROUTE? Why new macro was added instead of changing existing one?

Yes, because not every route is a Redfish route. For example, web socket routes.

Reviewers should reject BMCWEB_ROUTE for Redfish resources after this change is merged. But non-redfish route can still use BMCWEB_ROUTE

Is there a way to avoid the macro here?  They're technically disallowed by the coding standard.  The macro on line 27 was only allowed because it predates bmcweb (it came from crow).

Please follow the coding standard if you're able.  If you're not able, please provide documentation as to why (wither in an inline comment or in the commit message).
nit: This is a good place to use auto. If you have to add type on the right side of the expression you don't need to repeat it on the left side.
Yes, but I just follow the existing code. I can fix existing in another patch.
Ack
nit: Function above is marked as constexpr. You should be able to make Privileges::mappings also constexpr.

I intentionally made this non-const. Making |mapping| be able to change at runtime is the main idea in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/redfish-authorization.md.

The initialization function was made constexpr since in the design we proposed to implement base privilege registry (base mapping) at compile time. 

The |mapping| object will change at runtime in the following commit

Let me know if it makes sense :)
Ack

And you verified the permissions didn't change? E.g. you verified ReadOnly user can GET /redfish/v1/Chassis/<str>/ but not PATCH/POST?

You verified redfish::privileges::EntityTag::tagChassis is the correct privilege in both: 

    REDFISH_ROUTE(app, "/redfish/v1/Chassis/<str>/",
                  redfish::privileges::EntityTag::tagChassis,
                  boost::beast::http::verb::get)
    (std::bind_front(handleChassisGet, std::ref(app)));
    REDFISH_ROUTE(app, "/redfish/v1/Chassis/<str>/",
                  redfish::privileges::EntityTag::tagChassis,
                  boost::beast::http::verb::patch)
    (std::bind_front(handleChassisPatch, std::ref(app)));

I have verified NoAccess user is rejected in all resources that require a privilege. I can try this ReadOnly user.

Will do

+1 to the overall theme of "this needs a much larger tested statement".

We're messing with core privilege level things here that have significant potential to cause a CVE;  The level of testing expected here is going to be much higher.

Binary size testing?

Startup time testing?

Binary size testing: please take another look at commit message. Search binary size.

Startup time testing: I can add. Last time I test it there was no significant difference by looking at systemd timestamps. Do you have other options for testing this?

> Binary size testing: please take another look at commit message. Search binary size.

ACK.  I see this now.

> 
> Startup time testing: I can add. Last time I test it there was no significant difference by looking at systemd timestamps. Do you have other options for testing this?


When we did the same analysis years ago we did it with print statements, but if you can think of anything better, feel free to propose it.
Can this get broken up ? +2335 -2914  is a huge commit

I have split the unit test to the child.

To help view, I have added this note in commit message:

```
Please note: a large number of lines changed here is by the script,
specifically, |redfish-core/include/registries/privilege_registry.hpp|.
The majority of the change is in |http/routing.hpp|,
|redfish-core/include/privileges.hpp|, and |http/http_verbs.hpp|.
```

If you take out tree wide macro change, and the script generated |privilege_registry|. There is not a lot left. And I don't find an easy way to split this change further.
This commit still needs broken down.  As written it is too large to review, with that said, I've gone through and reviewed some of it to get a jump start on this.

Considering that Redfish defines every type by URL, should we be avoiding putting entityTag into REDFISH_ROUTE.  For example

REDFISH_ROUTE("/redfish/v1", EntityTag::tagSessionCollection)

Would be incorrect.

Today, we already have this issue. It's not that this commit introduces it.

I don't want to handle the complexity of inferring EntityTag from URL. This is called out in both design and this commit message. Do you have an idea about this inferring? Does it make sense to block this commit because of an existing issue?
The core routing layers should avoid having to know anything about Redfish.  They are intended to be reusable for non-redfish things.
Please put code moves in their own commit.  Also, please help to review the other commits that predate this making changes to the http verbs structures.
Same as above.  The core http layers should have no knowledge of Redfish.
This is the default, and considering we're using this as an index, shouldn't this be size_t?

Please make another attempt at these data structures below.  Just because this code is generated does not meant that it's acceptable for it to be unreadable, or not follow the coding standard.  This is a security data structure, it needs to be able to be audited easily.

The previous code stored essentially the same information.

Please take a look at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/58192/6

Storing bitmasks is called out in the design doc. The unit test guarantee any improper modification of this array results in test failures.

This is the most efficient way that I could think of. There is no easy way to store a two dimensional costexpr array.

To make these arrays readable, we can probably use a static map, if we accept it. 

> The previous code stored essentially the same information.

How do you generate a PrivilegeRegistry from previous code?
Unclear what this has to do with this commit.
I remember otherwise it doesn't compile. I can double check
Why do we need EntityTag in each one?

It is explained in the commit message. It's non-trivial to infer the EntityTag from the URL. Given that URL and corresponding handler is decided at
compile time, adding an Entity in compile time doesn't introduce much
toil. Tags are implemented as enum, thus no much space increased.

This commit doesn't increase binary size but filled a big gap that existing authz code has
